title: AHA Cerebral Venous Thrombosis Scientific Statement 2024

recommendations.text: Diagnosis of CVT is primarily based on MRI/MRV or CT/CTV; contrast-enhanced MRV or susceptibility-weighted imaging helps confirm cortical vein thrombosis.
Initial therapy: LMWH is preferred over UFH, and venous hemorrhage is not a contraindication to anticoagulation in CVT.
Transition to VKA (INR 2-3) for 3-12 months for transient risk factors or indefinite therapy for chronic/recurrent risk; DOACs may be reasonable in selected patients.
Endovascular therapy may be considered as rescue for clinical deterioration or failed/contraindicated anticoagulation; evidence for a superior technique is limited.
Decompressive craniectomy should be offered for severe CVT with parenchymal lesions and impending herniation as lifesaving therapy.
